Report.name: AGE-WELL's Project Scorecard and Reporting Framework

ReportSection.name: Overview
ReportSection.title: AGE-WELL's Project Scorecard and Reporting Framework
ReportSection.ReportItem: {$item}
ReportSection.Static:
The objectives of the NCE program are to mobilize multi-disciplinary research capacity from across Canada, engage partners from multiple academic institutions and various public and private-sector organizations, train the next generation of highly qualified people, work with end users to accelerate the creation and application of new knowledge as well as increase collaboration between research in Canada and abroad.

The aim of the form is to allow the RMC to assess the progress, performance against the key impact objectives of AGE-WELL and demonstrate that the network is effectively working to achieve our goals. Reporting is crucial to the ongoing success and future of AGE-WELL.

AGE-WELL produces products (technologies, services and policy) that MUST have impact. Progress towards achieving these products can be defined and measured across all projects in a consistent fashion. The Product Readiness Levels (PRL) is a method of estimating maturity and progress towards a product across a 9 point scale. It is based on the Technology Readiness Levels (TRL), which is a well-established approach in engineering and other fields. It has been adapted for use in AGE-WELL in order to be inclusive of the different types of products and research that our members conduct. Part of this adaptation has been adopting a modified scale that maps the original 9 TRL levels into 5 stages.

AGE-WELL has adapted both scales to be inclusive of the types of projects and products that are part of the Network. Please refer to the Product Readiness Levels Guideline for definitions of the PRL levels, as well as example outputs at each level across product type. Note that the current outputs in this table are only examples and will be added to as we continue to roll out this process, and we receive feedback from members of AGE-WELL.

Projects are required to justify the current PRL stage they are at so that we can track progress over time. It should be noted that it is expected that some projects may remain at a specific PRL longer than others. Justification and a demonstration of progress is required.

Each project is required to complete one table related to each of the 5 NCE objectives (Scientific Excellence, Networking and Partnerships, Knowledge Mobilization, Commercialization, and HQP Training) for the past year.

All projects are asked to complete the tables relevant to their project. These tables were developed based on the Balance Scorecard approach and will be used by the RMC to review projects against what was planned at last year’s report. Projects will only be reviewed against themselves and the progress they make towards the objectives they have set. RMC will also submit an overall summary of Core Research Program performance to AGE-WELL’s Board of directors based on an overview of project achievements. The outcome of the RMC review of each project will be used to make a recommendation to the AGE-WELL Board of Directors with respect to potential future investment, if renewed. Projects will only be reviewed against themselves and the progress they make towards the objectives they have set.

The report consists of qualitative and quantitative information to appropriately capture the progress your project is making on the key impact area.

The report requests two types of information:

  1. Narrative: a short written account of what the project has accomplished to achieve impact; and
  2. Metrics: quantitative data (most values are auto populated via reporting on Forum), substantiating information must be provided for all entered values;

For more information on the development of this evaluation or instructions please watch the Webinar posted on the Intranet. You can also find a Word version of the form here if you would like to work offline.

ReportSection.name: Assessment & Readiness
ReportSection.title: Project Assessment and Readiness Level
ReportSection.Static: Projects can be at different stages of product readiness, from concept to deployment and adoption. Please refer to the guidelines in order to define which stage best characterises your project.

ReportItem.options: Technology product - a device or system that someone will buy or adopt|Policy/practice product - information that will be used by stakeholder or end-user, including others in the network|Service product - a service or information product that will be used by another entity

ReportSection.ReportItem:
Product Description

What kind of product(s) are you developing (check all that apply):

{$item}

Describe the outcome of your project and the potential added value of what you have completed over the past year.

{$item}

Product Development

AGE-WELL is expected to deliver significant economic benefits through new products, enterprises, improved services and the net monetary value of improved health and independence of seniors and caregivers. How will the outcomes of your project benefit the Canadian economy and what progress has your project made in achieving these outcomes?

{$item}

AGE-WELL is expected to have significant benefits to Canadian society through improved quality of life of older adults and their caregivers, health and independence of seniors, improved policy, practice and services. How will the outcomes of your project eventually benefit the Canadian society? Provide any demonstrated evidence of the impact of service or knowledge products on key health and quality of life outcomes relevant to healthy aging.

{$item}

How many products has your project developed?

{$item}

Use the attached supporting documents (AGE-WELL PRL Guidelines), determine the “Product Readiness Level” (PRL) your product(s) currently at:

PRL Levels
  • INNOVATION RESEARCH (PRL 1) basic principles observed
  • INCUBATOR (PRL 2-3) technology concept formulated; experimental proof of concept
  • PROTOTYPE (PRL 4-5) technology validated in lab; technology validated in relevant environment (industrially relevant environment in the case of key enabling technologies)
  • EXPERIMENTAL IMPLEMENTATION (PRL 6-7) technology demonstrated in relevant environment (industrially relevant environment in the case of key enabling technologies); system prototype demonstration in operational environment
  • OUTCOMES (PRL 8-9) system complete and qualified; actual system proven in operational environment (competitive manufacturing in the case of key enabling technologies; or in space)

{$item}

ReportSection.name: Networking/Partnerships
ReportSection.title: Networking and Partnerships
ReportSection.Static:
AGE-WELL Network is expected to demonstrate that the projects have brought together the key individuals and organizations needed to generate and implement multifaceted solutions to the complex challenges it is designed to address. It should be built on relationships with partners and the receptor community that will accelerate the activities, outcomes and impact of the project.

  • the social innovations to be implemented as a result of the Network  and the extent to which these will contribute to more effective public policy in Canada;
  • effective collaboration with the private, public and not-for-profit sectors in technology, market development, and public policy development;
  • the extent to which the Network will help the partners develop strong receptor capacity to exploit current and future research breakthroughs;

ReportSection.name: KTEE
ReportSection.title: Knowledge & Technology Exchange and Exploitation
ReportSection.Static: NCE Networks are expected to generate social and economic benefits by ensuring the rapid flow of knowledge, ideas and innovations from researchers to Canadian receptors. Projects are expected to demonstrate that the appropriate activities will be undertaken and the appropriate resources allocated to maximize those benefits through effective stakeholder engagement and communication.

ReportSection.name: HQP Training
ReportSection.Static: Training is expected to add value to the formal training initiatives already available through the academic community and should aim at helping HQP find employment in the Canadian economy, particularly in sectors related to technology and aging. HQP should be directly involved in the range of activities in a multi-disciplinary team research project and should work closely with industry and community partners and be involved in collaborating within the Age-Well research network and partner universities.

ReportSection.name: PRL Justifications
ReportSection.title: PRL Justifications & Next Steps
ReportSection.ReportItem:
Use the information you have filled out above to give a justification for the PRL that you have selected including progress made over the past year from one level to the next. If you have not progressed to another PRL provide justification for why.

{$item}

Which PRL level do you expect to be at in one year from now? Provide a brief justification and key steps you will be taking to move to the next level

{$item}

What are the next steps for your project and developed products? Describe how you will leverage AGE-WELL activities moving forward. Will you apply for outside funding? Will you apply for AGE-WELL funding, if renewed? What kind of funding will you need to advance your product?

{$item}

AGE-WELL’s Core Research Program is a set of integrated, long-term research projects that are the cornerstone of the Network’s activities. What has your team learned over the past 4.5 years that you wish you had known in your first year? What knowledge have you learned that you would pass on to future CRP AGE-WELL researchers, if renewed?

{$item}

Please provide a short case study of outstanding work or achievement in any of the above evaluation impact areas (Scientific Excellence, Networking and Partnerships, Knowledge Mobilization, Commercialization and HQP Training). Case studies provide an opportunity for a better understanding of the work being completed and its impact in the real world. These stories are a great opportunity to promote the amazing work being accomplished within AGE-WELL. We will draw on these case studies as we prepare our network renewal applications.

The following should be provided for the case study:
  • A clear explanation of the process or means through which the research led to, underpinned or made a contribution to the impact (for example, how it was disseminated, how it came to influence users or beneficiaries, or how it came to be exploited, taken up or applied).
  • Where the case study was part of a wider body of research that contributed to the impact (for example, where there has been research collaboration with other institutions or grants), the case study should specify the particular contribution of the case study and acknowledge other key research contributions.
  • Details of the beneficiaries – who or what community, constituency or organisation has benefitted, been affected or impacted on.
  • Details of the nature of the impact – how they have benefitted, been affected or impacted on.
  • Evidence or indicators of the extent of the impact described, as appropriate to the case being made.
  • Dates of when these impacts occurred.
{$item}
